Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Elucidating Chemical Mechanisms of DNA Repair Using Transition State Analogs
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Sheila David at The University of California - Davis and Dr. Martin Horvath at The University of Utah to investigate how DNA damage is detected and repaired. DNA is the blueprint for life, and damage to this molecule caused by cellular metabolism or by environmental hazards can lead to mutations, cell death or changes in the blueprint over the course of evolution. The preservation of DNA relies on the action of DNA repair enzymes. Despite years of work that has uncovered DNA repair enzymes and the types of damage upon which they act, mysteries remain as to how these amazing enzymes work at the chemical level. This project uses synthetic DNA chemistry and X-ray crystallography to trap and visualize steps, in the DNA repair process, that are otherwise too fleeting to study. This strategy provides a detailed molecular picture of the DNA repair process. The project applies a multi-faceted approach to investigate several enzymes that specialize in repairing damaged DNA bases. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project are receiving training in synthesis, biochemistry and X-ray crystallography. The discoveries and results produced by this project are being incorporated into a DNA damage and repair undergraduate laboratory class at UC Davis and at the University of Utah. Undergraduate students in these courses will emerge with skills in critical thinking and conceptual knowledge related to how the information of life is encoded in DNA and maintained by DNA repair enzymes.

This research project delineates chemical mechanisms of base excision repair (BER) glycosylases and illuminates how these enzymes efficiently find rare modified DNA bases. Modified nucleotides that mimic transition states are being prepared through synthetic chemistry. Structural studies of several BER glycosylases bound to DNA containing these transition state analogs are revealing the strategies used by these enzymes to catalyze base excision. Preliminary work has revealed several surprising features of the BER glycosylases MutY and AlkD, and prompted novel structural and mechanistic studies on these and related BER glycosylases. This project is revealing common themes and unique features in the chemistry underlying DNA repair.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division supported  Sheila David at UC Davis and Dr. Martin Horvath at University of Utah to investigate how DNA damage is detected and repaired. DNA is the blueprint for life, and damage to this molecule caused by cellular metabolism or by environmental hazards can lead to mutations, cell death, or changes in the blueprint over the course of evolution. The preservation of DNA relies on the action of DNA repair enzymes.  Despite years of work that have uncovered DNA repair enzymes and the types of damage they act upon, mysteries remain as to how these amazing enzymes work at the molecular level.  In this project, synthetic DNA chemistry and X-ray crystallography was used to trap and visualize steps in the DNA repair process that otherwise are too fleeting to study.  Using this multifaceted strategy, we uncovered several surprising new features of DNA glycosylases that find rare subtle modification of DNA bases in a process called base excision repair (BER).   For example, structural studies revealed how the MutY glycosylase recognizes an oxidized form of guanine (called OG) that differs by only a single oxygen atom over its normal G counterpart!  In addition, using a mimic of a reaction intermediate we trapped the AlkC glycosylase and the structure revealed how this enzyme recognizes and excises a variety of different sized modified DNA bases by not flipping the base out of the DNA helix like other glycosylases.  We also created new synthetic tools that may be used by us and other scientist to trap and visual DNA repair enzymes in action or as starting points for developing molecules that may target and inhibit the repair activity of DNA repair enzymes in cells.  This work illustrates how these remarkable enzymes efficiently recognize and excise only damaged bases without compromising the rest of the genome.  This work has revealed common themes and unique features in the chemistry underlying DNA repair.  This fundamental insight impacts chemistry of life processes related to a broad arrays of disciplines including genomics, environmental sciences, evolution and biotechnology.

 

Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project have acquired interdisciplinary training spanning synthetic nucleic acid chemistry, nucleic acid enzymology, and DNA-protein crystallography.  They have learned important lessons in how to combine different approaches to unlock key features of fundamental life processes.  The discoveries and results produced by this project also form the cornerstone of two distinct and unique DNA damage and repair laboratory classes for undergraduates taught at UC Davis and the University of Utah. Undergraduates in these courses emerge with skills in critical thinking and conceptual knowledge related to how the information of life is encoded in DNA and maintained by DNA repair enzymes. Both PIs are committed to activities that broaden participation in science, including activities that foster favorable environments for women and minority undergraduate and graduate students.  The rigorous scientific training provided for students working directly on the research project in the laboratory, and the students involved in the associated courses will provide the basis for them to make contributions to society in many ways, such as in careers in industry, academia, science policy and law.
